Effect of the zirconia-titania catalyst modification and CO2/CH4 ratios on CO2 coupling reaction with methane Emad N. Al-Shafei Conceptualization Methodology Validation Writing – original draft ⁎ Mohammed Z. Albahar Conceptualization Methodology Writing – review & editing Mohammad F. Aljishi Investigation Validation Writing – original draft Hameed H. Al-Badairy Methodology Investigation Validation Research and Development Center, Saudi Aramco, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia Research and Development Center Saudi Aramco Dhahran Saudi Arabia Research and Development Center, Saudi Aramco, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia ⁎ Corresponding author. The CO2 utilization for coupling reaction with methane for the production of C1 building block chemicals was studied. The influence of surface oxides of zirconia-titania catalysts and CO2/methane gas ratios were investigated to promote methane activation and coupling with CO2 for the production of value-added chemicals of acetic acid, ethane and ethylene. The synthesized catalysts by three impregnation methods assisted by microwave irradiation, exhibited different nanoscale crystal sizes and were characterized by various techniques of XRD, TEM, BET, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR. The anatase and tetragonal phases of ZrO2/TiO2 framework were identified and the synthesized catalysts showed an increase of surface acidity with distinct H2 reduction patterns for each catalyst as result of Zr oxide interaction with Ti oxide. Methane activation was observed and the coupling reaction produced ethane and ethylene and was affected via modified catalysts. Despite ongoing reaction, CO2 coupling reaction formulated acetic acid and consumed methyl surface species over catalyst then dimerized to form ethane and ethylene. It was found that the obtained products from CO2 coupling were altered by the variation in methane dissociation due to changing CO2/methane ratios, at which higher CO2/methane ratio (90%:10%) showed the highest methane dissociation and CO2 coupling reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords C1 building block molecules CO2 utilization CO2 coupling Methane coupling Acetic acid 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) utilization and conversion into high value chemicals is an important strategy for CO2 capture efforts [1–3]. Several studies examined the utilization of CO2 for the production of hydrogen fuel through dry reforming of methane [4,5] and high-value chemicals via coupling of whole CO2 molecules into fine chemicals, such as salicylic acid [6,7], and polymers such as dimethyl carbonate [8,9]. Recent studies have focused on developing catalysts for direct CO2 coupling with methane to produce acetic acid. Acetic acid is synthesized mainly through several carbonylation reaction steps of methanol with carbon monoxide (CO) over Rhodium (Rh), Iridium (Ir), Cobalt (Co) based catalysts [10,11]. Although, several studies utilized one step carboxylation reaction to convert both methane and CO2 into acetic acid [12], the reaction remains challenging due to the limitation of the thermodynamic barrier [12–14]. Recently, several catalysts were developed to assist the one step reaction of CO2 with methane by utilizing platinum (Pt) [15], palladium (Pd) [15], copper (Cu) [12], Iron (Fe) [14] and copper vanadium (Cu-V) [16–18] based catalysts. Density functional theory (DFT) was utilized to investigate the reaction mechanism of methane and carbon dioxide activation over selected catalysts [13,14,19]. Latimer 2017 [20] and Aljama 2017 [21] studies the CH bond of methane activation over metal oxides catalysts and they suggested CH bond of methane activated via surface intermediate pathway and the transition state, the bond of CH is stretched and dissociated to methyl surface species interact with metal of the catalyst whereas the hydrogen is interacts with the oxygen in the metal oxide catalyst. Accordingly the initiation step includes the catalytic dehydrogenation of methane to methyl and hydrogen surface species followed by carbonylation reaction of adsorbed species of CO2. Then, hydrogenation step proceeds to produce acetic acid, as shown in Eqs. (1)–(4) [14,19,22]. Wu et al. [13] applied DFT and NMR to study the formation of acetic acid from direct conversion of CH4 and CO2 over bifunctional catalyst of Zn/H−ZSM-5 and the acidic sites promote an essential role for final formation of acetic acid via proton transfer to the acetate surface species to acetic acid. Another DFT and experimental study by Shavi et al. [23] on direct conversion of CH4 and CO2 whereas the Lewis acid sites of Zn-Ce oxide in the catalyst promotes a significant role in surface carbonylation reaction of CH4. (1) C H 4 + * * → C H 3 * + H * (2) C O 2 + * → C O 2 * (3) C H 3 * + C O 2 * → C H 3 COO * + * (4) C H 3 COO * + H * → C H 3 COOH + 2 * Several studies investigated ZrO2 and TiO2 based catalysts for methane dehydrogenation via oxidative coupling to formulate ethane and ethylene [24,25]. It was reported that increasing ZrO2 loading to TiO2 framework results in increasing the surface acidity [25–28]. Chen et al. [29] studied the DFT of the acidic-basic properties by adsorption CO and CO2 over bifunctional TiO2-ZrO2 catalyst and highlighted a moderate Lewis acid sites of TiO2-ZrO2, whereas TiO2 had a weak basic character while ZrO2 had strong basic properties. Likewise, Manrı́quez et al. reported the ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst consisted of mix acidic-basic sites and the properties were determined by FTIR-pyridine and FTIR-CO2 [30,31]. Zr-Ti oxide catalysts showed high reactivity in several studies utilizing CO2 to assist dehydrogenation reactions [32–34], where ZrO2/TiO2 catalysts helped in generating surface species from methane and promoted reaction with CO2 to formulate acetic acid [35]. In this paper, three impregnated catalysts were studied to understand methane dissociation, coupling with CO2 and dimerization reactions to form acetic acid, ethane and ethylene. In the present investigation, the physicochemical properties and the influence of surface oxides of ZrO2/TiO2 catalysts were correlated with catalytic coupling reactions. In addition, the study was extended to investigate the adsorption effect of gas ratios of CO2 with methane to assist the coupling reaction proceeding for C1 building block. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization In this study, zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate and titanium (IV) oxide were acquired from Fisher Scientific. The catalyst preparation was assisted by microwave energy (500 W) at 120 ᵒC for 2 h to synthesize 5% ZrO2/TiO2 and three wet impregnation methods were applied [36]. In Method-1, labelled as M1, the precursor catalyst was made by dissolving 0.33 g ZrO(NO3)2•6H2O in deionized water (70 ml). Method-2 (M2) utilized diluted nitric acid (0.2 N, 70 ml) to dissolve zirconium (IV) oxynitrate. Method-3 (M3) utilized diluted ammonia hydroxide (1 N, 70 ml) to dissolve zirconium (IV) oxynitrate. Then a 3.3 g of titanium dioxide was added to the dissolved zirconium nitrate solutions and the precursor solutions were transffered to 100 ml PTFE pot for micorwave irridation for 2 h. Then, all samples were washed by reverse osmosis (RO) water two times and dried at 90 °C for 20 h at a vacuum oven. Then, the dried precursors were calcined at 700 ᵒC in a high temperature furnace. 2.2 Catalyst characterization After calcination, the synthesized catalysts of 5% ZrO2/TiO2 were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD, Panalytical X'Pert PRO Diffractometer) to distinguish crystalline structures of catalysts. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM-2100F) was utilized to determine the nanocrystal size and shape of prepared catalysts. Furthermore, the textural properties of the catalyst were measured by N2 adsorption using Micromeritics ASAP 2420. Also, the ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) technique was carried out by HIDEN CATLAB and CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) Micromeritics Autochem 2910 instruments, to determine surface acidity and basicity of the catalyst. Finally, the temperature programmed hydrogen reduction (H2-TPR) analysis was conducted to determine the catalyst reduction using Micromeritics Autochem 2910. 2.3 Catalytic reactivity test The coupling reaction of CO2 with methane was studied by using quartz packed bed reactor installed into a vertical furnace of CATLAB unit from of HIDEN. The CATLAB consisted of two units, a reactor furnace and online quadrupole mass spectrometer for gas analysis by using QIC-20/HIDEN. Three gas ratios of CO2/methane were applied in the experiments and the ratios applied were 90%:10%, 50%:50%, and 10%:90% at gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 140 h−1 at atmospheric pressure. The catalytic reaction of CO2 was conducted by loading 0.30 g of catalyst and pre-heating the catalyst to 550 ᵒC for 90 min in He atmosphere and then the reactor cooled down to 300 ᵒC before conducting coupling reaction of CO2 with methane. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Crystalline phase identification The X-ray diffraction analysis for of 5% Zr oxide over TiO2 support synthesised by three methods of impregnation are shown in Fig. 1 . The diffraction peaks showed the anatase crystalline of three prepared catalysts whereas no ZrO2 peak was observed for the samples prepared from the precursor diluted in RO water or in aqueous nitric acid for the impregnation methods (M1) and (M2), as observed in earlier studies [26,37,38]. However, the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 was observed at 20°, 35.1°, 50.3° and 69.8° 2theta in the sample prepared with the precursor based on diluted ammonia hydroxide (M3). Fig. 2 shows that the peak intensity of anatase crystalline (1 0 1) and (2 0 0) at 25.3° and 48° 2theta of synthesized catalysts were slightly affected from incorporating ZrO2 over TiO2. The study estimated the crystallite diameter of catalysts prepared by three impregnation methods using Scherrer equation and the data is presented in Table 1 . The average size of catalyst crystals was increased from 12.7 nm of pure TiO2 to 22–27 nm after incorporating ZrO2 to TiO2 support, similar to crystallite sizes observed in earlier studies [39,40]. 3.2 Surface topographies TEM topography of the three synthesised catalysts showed aggregated rounded nanocrystal particles between 20 and 37 nm as illustrated in Fig. 3 [A], [B] and [C]. An average size of 30–37 nm was observed for the catalysts synthesised using methods M1 and M2. However, the precursor from diluted ammonia hydroxide impregnation method (M3) showed an average size of 22 nm, which is slightly smaller compared to the other catalysts. Overall, the TEM topographies for the catalysts are in line with XRD analysis and observations by other studies [39,41]. 3.3 The textural properties of catalyst The textural properties of the synthesised ZrO2/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Table 1. It can be seen that the surface areas and pore volumes were found to be slightly higher compared to the properties of TiO2 used as support which is similar observation by Rao et al. [34]. Although the x-ray diffraction peaks were not observable for ZrO2 crystalline phase in the case of catalysts made by methods M1 and M2, the enhancement of the textural properties indicated that ZrO2 was successfully incorporated over TiO2. Furthermore, the pore size distribution of the synthesised catalysts was increased after the addition of ZrO2 to TiO2. Also, as shown in Fig. 4 , each catalyst showed unique pore size distribution as a result of the varied ZrO2 nucleation and growth over TiO2 from the different synthesis methods. 3.4 Hydrogen redaction and surface acidity/basicity of catalysts Fig. 5 illustrates the H2-TPR diagram of three catalysts synthesized by three different impregnation methods. Each catalyst showed broad peak of reduction with different maximum temperature peak (Tmax). This indicated the incorporated surface oxides of ZrO2 with TiO2 were affected by the impregnation methods. The reference sample of pure ZrO2 showed a stable surface oxide framework compared to the surface oxide of pure TiO2, which showed hydrogen reduction peak at Tmax >800 ᵒC due to reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ and the TPR peak at temperature higher >820 ᵒC suggested further reduction of Ti3+ to Ti2+ oxide [42,43]. The reduction of three catalysts of 5% ZrO2/TiO2 (M1, M2 and M3) showed shifted Tmax peak of Ti4+and was effected by Zr oxide interaction with the Ti oxide. Table 1 and Fig. 5 show that the synthesized sample with impregnation method (M2) exhibited broader peak of hydrogen reduction from the surface oxides ZrO2/TiO2. Also, it demonstrated the highest hydrogen reduction shown by the higher NH3 desorption than other catalysts made by methods (M1) and (M3). The acidity of the three catalysts was studied using NH3-TPD. It can be observed from Fig. 6 that ammonia desorption increased as result from incorporating ZrO2 on TiO2 catalysts compared to low acidity of pure TiO2 support. The synthesized catalysts showed 3–4 times higher surface acidity (138–215 µmolg−1) than pure TiO2, as presented in Table 1. The catalyst prepared by impregnation method (M2) showed the highest acidity amongst all catalysts with broader peak despite the low pore volume measured by N2 adsorption, as shown in Figs. 4 and 6. The crystallite size was found to be correlated with TPD acidity for combined transition metal based catalysts and the smaller size crystal would contribute more to surface acidity, as presented in Table 1, which is an agreement with earlier findings by Rao et al. [39] and Nishiwaki et al. [44]. The CO2-TPR utilized to study the basicity of catalyst of 5% ZrO2/TiO2 (M1, M2 and M3) as presented in Table 1 and Fig. 1S, ultimately during catalyst impregnation preparation the surface basicity was increased [34]. The catalyst of 5% ZrO2/TiO2 (M2) showed weaker surface basicity and low CO2 adsorb concentration than other prepared catalysts (M1 and M3). The weak CO2 adsorption of 5% ZrO2/TiO2 (M2) indicated that the catalyst probably has more surface acidity from ZrO2 incorporated over TiO2. While other prepared catalysts (M1 and M3) showed more surface basicity but weaker acidity than 5% ZrO2/TiO2 (M2). Ultimately, each prepared catalyst showed unique pore size distribution, surface acidity and substantial basicity to increase the feasibility of methane and CO2 adsorption [23] as a result of the ZrO2 nucleation diversified and interaction with TiO2. 3.5 Effect of the catalysts synthesis 3.5.1 CO2 coupling with methane to acetic acid formation The production of C1 carbon block molecule via coupling reaction of CO2 and methane was studied over bifunctional ZrO2/TiO2 catalyst [29,31] prepared by three different impregnation methods. The hydrogen reduction and enhanced acid-base properties strength determined by ammonia and CO2-TPD indicated of different interaction between ZrO2-TiO2 of three catalysts. The surface basicity of ZrO2/TiO2 catalyst promotes likely the hydrogen abstraction and CO2 over catalyst surface [45]. Nie 2020 [14] and Zhao 2016 [46] emphasized the sufficient balance between methyl surface species (CH3*) of methane activation barrier with adsorbed CO2 for CC coupling to produce acetic acid over bimetallic catalyst. Latimer 2017 [20] and Aljama 2017 [21] suggested the hydrogen (H*) from methane dehydrogenation which interacts with oxygen atom of metal oxide catalyst, the weakest interaction with oxygen surface is more active metal oxide catalyst. The coupling reaction was carried out at gas ratio of CO2/methane (50%:50%) at atmospheric pressure. Fig. 7 shows the acetic acid formation from methane activation and dissociation [47] considering the CH3*, CH2* and H* surface species [48] made over the catalyst and coupled with CO2, while the acetic acid concentration and yield were evidently affected by the catalyst preparation method (Table S1). The catalysts prepared by impregnation methods (M2) and (M3) using precursor from diluted nitric acid and ammonia hydroxide showed higher methane conversion with higher coupling with CO2 to form acetic acid in the range of 5500 to 6500 ppm with yield of 1.1 and 1.4% respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 7. Alternatively, the catalyst synthesized 1% and 5% ZrO2/TiO2 by method M1 with a precursor made from wet impregnation with RO water delivered the lowest selectivity CO2 coupling reaction with methane and the insertion reaction started at lower reaction temperature (530 ᵒC) to produce acetic acid with a range of 380–780 ppm (Figs. 7 and S2). Considering the difference in reduction and acidity behaviour of the three catalysts, each catalyst demonstrated a notably different catalytic activation behaviour of methane conversion and acetic acid selectivity to promote coupling reaction with CO2. Shavi et al. [23] and Rabie et al. [12] emphasized that catalyst acidic sites promote the hydrogen transfer to the surface species of acetate (CH3COO*) surface species to acetic acid (Eq. (4)). 3.5.2 Methane coupling to ethane and ethylene In the present reaction of CO2 coupling with methane, ethane and ethylene were produced as result of methane dissociation and coupling [49], as demonstrated in Fig. 8 A and B. Methane activation over the catalyst led to dehydrogenation of methane to methyl (CH3*) and methylene (CH2*) surface species [47] which are eventually dimerized to produce ethane and ethylene. Although that acetic acid produced from CO2 coupling with methane was obtained at high concentration and consumed the surface species molecules from methane over catalysts, the catalyst preparation methods significantly influenced CH bond activation of methane and coupling reactions. The 1% and 5% ZrO2/TiO2 (M-1) catalyst, which was prepared via precursor from wet impregnation with RO water, showed higher methyl surface species with the dimerization reaction to produce ethane gas being more favourable than the CO2 coupling reaction to produce acetic acid, as shown Figs. 7 and 8A and S3[A]&[B]. However, the catalyst tendency to generate methylene surface species and dimerize it to ethylene was low. Similarly, the catalyst ZrO2/TiO2 (M2), which was prepared from wet impregnation with diluted nitric acid, showed conversion of methane to methyl and methylene surface species, at similar temperature of acetic acid formation, before being dimerized to produce ethane and ethylene, as presented in Fig. 8A and B. On the other hand, although the catalyst of ZrO2/TiO2 (M3) showed activation of methane to methyl surface species and coupled to ethane at similar temperature of acetic acid formation, while no ethylene formation was detected. Therefore, surfaces oxide of catalysts prepared by three different impregnations methods of ZrO2/TiO2 exhibited different catalyst surface properties altered the catalytic performance through surface activation of methane and CH dissociation [47] to produce ethane and ethylene [49] through dimerization alongside coupling reaction with CO2 to produce acetic acid. 3.6 Effect of the CO2/methane ratios Jensen et al. (2021) studied the methane activation increased with higher CO2/methane and effected by temperature [50]. Therefore, the effect of gas ratios of CO2/methane [51] were studied over ZrO2/TiO2 (M2) catalyst which showed higher dissociation of methane and coupling reaction than other catalysts. Three ratios of CO2/methane at 90%:10%, 50%:50%, and 10%:90% were selected, and CO2 coupling with methane to form acetic acid was affected by changing these ratios, as demonstrated in Fig. 9 and Table S1. The higher methane conversion with highest acetic acid yield of 8.9% (8300–8800 ppm) with selectivity increased to 15.5%, was formed with CO2/methane 90%:10% under higher reaction temperature compared to other CO2/methane ratios. That suggested the coupling reaction was hindered by CO2 adsorption over catalyst as well as the lower formation of methyl and hydrogen surface species due to the limited accessibility of methane to the catalyst surface. At the same time, high production of ethane than ethylene observed within the same temperature range, as illustrated in Fig. 10 A and B, suggests that methane dehydrogenation over catalysts surface species via CH3* and CH2* formation is coupled at similar temperature to that of acetic acid formation. Alternatively, the amount of formed acetic acid declined to 1395–1660 ppm as the adsorbed amount of CO2 over the catalyst decreased at gas ratio of CO2/methane 10%:90% due to the methane conversion and selectivity decreased to 3.3% and 5.3%. In addition, as presented in Fig. 10A and B, concentration of ethane and ethylene by methane dissociation followed by dimerization is low compared with other gas ratios. Ultimately the CO2/methane 50%:50% initiated the coupling reaction of CO2 with methane conversion at lower temperatures than the other gas ratios, at which the highest formation of acetic acid was observed to be in the range of 5500 to 6500 ppm while the yield was made 1.4%. The methane dissociation over the catalyst surface to methyl and hydrogen surface species and following reaction with CO2 was affected by the adsorption over the catalyst surface and the accessibility of adsorbed CO2 from various CO2/methane ratios. The study demonstrates that CO2 coupling with methane involves methane dissociation [47] over catalyst surface with the final obtained product range being affected by surface oxides of synthesized ZrO2/TiO2 catalysts. It was observed that the dimerization reaction to ethane and ethylene was occurring concurrently alongside CO2 coupling reaction. The obtained products were altered by CO2/methane ratios and the ratio of 50%:50% displayed the highest tendency towards CO2 coupling reaction with methane to produce acetic acid similar observation by Rabie et al. [12], as well as ethane and ethylene. On the other hand, CO2/methane ratio of 90%:10% presented the highest yield of acetic acid (8.9%) while the coupling reaction was hindered by CO2 adsorption [52] over catalyst and accessibility of methane dissociation over catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) utilized to examine the reaction activation between CH4 and CO2 to synthesis acetic acid over catalysts [13,14,19] and reaction mechanism showed that the initiation step includes the catalytic dehydrogenation of methane to methyl and hydrogen surface species followed by carbonylation reaction of adsorbed species of CO2 and then executed by hydrogenation step to produce acetic acid [14,19,22]. The methane reaction and coupling with CO2 to formulate acetic acid over 5% ZrO2/TiO2 catalysts was reported in our earlier work [35]. Fig. 11 illustrates the reaction network and the initiation step of methane dehydrogenation and CO2 activation over the catalyst to generate radical surface species of methyl (CH3*), methylene (CH2*), hydrogen (H*) and CO2*. At reaction temperature (>530 ᵒC), formation of methane and ethylene gas product (Fig. 8, Table S1) indicated of methyl (CH3*) and methylene (CH2*) radical surface species generated from dissociation of methane and coupling over catalyst. At a similar reaction temperature, the adsorbed surface species of CH3* and CH2* react with adsorbed surface species of CO2* and follow the hydrogenation step to produce acetic acid, as shown in the reaction scheme of Fig. 11 [14,19,22]. Table S1 shows hydrogen was also produced from methane dehydrogenation over catalyst at similar reaction temperature of acetic acid formation and the hydrogenation reaction is essential step for adsorbed surface species of acetate (CH3COO*) over catalyst [14,19]. Table S1 showed water formation from methane dehydrogenation and CO2 activation that indicated of the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) was active and consumed adsorbed H* surface species from the catalyst surface and reacted with CO2 in one step reaction. 4 Conclusions The influence of surface oxides of ZrO2/TiO2 catalysts on CO2 coupling reaction with methane through three impregnation methods was investigated. The TEM showed that three catalysts had different crystalline size from ZrO2 loaded over TiO2 and was in alignment with TPR analysis which showed distinct surfaces oxides reduction profile for each catalyst due to Zr oxide interaction to Ti oxide. All synthesized catalysts showed 3–4 times higher acidity than the pure TiO2 despite the obtained lower surface areas. The formation of acetic acid from methane dissociation to methyl and hydrogen surface species coupled with CO2 was affected by surfaces oxides synthesized with different impregnation methods. On the other hand, the coupling of methane to ethane and ethylene suggested that methane dissociate to methyl and methylene surface species is followed by dimerization reaction. Although the surface species are consumed mainly for coupling reaction with CO2 both coupling reactions are affected by catalyst synthesis of preparation method. Finally, the CO2/methane gas ratio played a key role in controlling the extent of reaction and showed a direct effect on CO2 coupling with methane in terms of molecular adsorption and dissociation over catalyst surface. coredata.dc:description: The CO2 utilization for coupling reaction with methane for the production of C1 building block chemicals was studied. The influence of surface oxides of zirconia-titania catalysts and CO2/methane gas ratios were investigated to promote methane activation and coupling with CO2 for the production of value-added chemicals of acetic acid, ethane and ethylene. The synthesized catalysts by three impregnation methods assisted by microwave irradiation, exhibited different nanoscale crystal sizes and were characterized by various techniques of XRD, TEM, BET, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR. The anatase and tetragonal phases of ZrO2/TiO2 framework were identified and the synthesized catalysts showed an increase of surface acidity with distinct H2 reduction patterns for each catalyst as result of Zr oxide interaction with Ti oxide. Methane activation was observed and the coupling reaction produced ethane and ethylene and was affected via modified catalysts. Despite ongoing reaction, CO2 coupling reaction formulated acetic acid and consumed methyl surface species over catalyst then dimerized to form ethane and ethylene. It was found that the obtained products from CO2 coupling were altered by the variation in methane dissociation due to changing CO2/methane ratios, at which higher CO2/methane ratio (90%:10%) showed the highest methane dissociation and CO2 coupling reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of the zirconia-titania catalyst modification and CO2/CH4 ratios on CO2 coupling reaction with methane
